title: On 1 August 2019, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be higher, the same, or lower than it was on 31 January 2019?
preds:
Since this question is all but finished, I figured now would be a good time to go in and analyze my thinking for my own education (spoiler: I got my face ripped off). My forecasts for the question were as follows (H: higher, S: same, L: lower):
2/17 - S: 88, H: 8, L: 4
3/17 - S: 78, H: 11, L: 11
3/24 - S: 78, H: 2, L: 20
4/5 - S: 67, H: 17, L: 16
4/27: S: 75, H:15, L: 10
5/25 - S: 85, H:10, L: 5
5/31 - S: 80, H: 5, L: 15
6/4 - S: 70, H: 5, L: 20
6/7 - S: 60, H: 0, L: 40
6/19 - S: 67, H: 0, L: 33
6/28 - S: 72, H: 0, L: 28
6/30 - S: 76, H: 0, L: 24
7/5 - S: 76, H: 0, L: 24
7/10 - S: 43, H: 0, L: 57
7/11 - S: 15, H: 0, L: 85
7/15 - S: 10, H: 0, L: 90
7/29 - S: 5, H: 0, L: 95 This question was an interesting one for me because I started out more confident in no changes even though consensus expectations were for multiple rate hikes in 2019. I noted that economic indicators seemed solid and inflation remained weak despite a strong labor market. I saw increasing inflation as the biggest risk which was reflected in the upside potential I carried through May. That was a key part of my first mistake - I failed to adequately weight a lot of the research I was reading on lower inflation expectations in a highly globalized and technology-dependent economy. I'm not saying "I should have known", but rather that I failed to incorporate this at all and just assumed inflation had to pick up.  Throughout the Spring though it became clear that devolving trade negotiations and weaker global growth were pushing the Fed towards holding flat. This pushed me to my second (and in my opinion - fatal - mistake). I discounted two factors early on which ultimately pushed the Fed to cut rates - global growth and insurance. I didn't think the insurance rationale meshed with the Fed's data-driven approach, but didn't consider the fact that in a low-interest rate environment, 25bps ain't what it used to be and the Fed would need to act fast. I also ignored the sentiment that the Fed would consider more than just the US outlook when setting rates due to global inter-connectedness because I didn't agree that that was their mandate. Ultimately, the take-aways here were:
1. Question the market implied probabilities, but listen to their rationales
2. Think more broadly and put yourself in policy-makers' shoes when considering outcomes
3. Don't wait for new information to materially alter your base case, slowly feed it in at the fringes. Better to walk back a 5 point adjustment than make a 40 point adjustment a month later
"Fed cuts rates, signals it may not need to do more." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed/fed-cuts-rates-signals-it-may-not-need-to-do-more-idUSKCN1UQ0DS

Got this from the Fed website: This is what the Fed Says their job is:
    Conducting the nation's monetary policy by influencing money and credit conditions in the economy in pursuit of full employment and stable prices.
    Supervising and regulating banks and other important financial institutions to ensure the safety and soundness of the nation's banking and financial system and to protect the credit rights of consumers.
    Maintaining the stability of the financial system and containing systemic risk that may arise in financial markets.
    Providing certain financial services to the U.S. government, U.S. financial institutions, and foreign official institutions, and playing a major role in operating and overseeing the nation's payments systems. I had always assumed the fed's job was primarily about preserving the value of our fiat currency via helping mitigate inflation (or preserve it at a 2% rate more or or less).  My initial prediction for lowering rates was based on that assumption and with a target goal of 2% and inflation <1.5% it seemed like it was in the feds best interest to lower rates to bump up inflation.   I decided to look at what the fed sees it's job as (see above) and only saw no reference to inflation (other than "stable prices").  With unemployment low and an historically high equities market, I'm not sure they'll feel motivated to cut rates.  With rates still low from a historic perspective, cutting them now will leave them less room to negotiate what they see as a looming global slowdown in the future.  That said, the market has priced in a cut, maybe somewhat less so than previously, so not cutting would likely lead to a market drop which could be seen as the catalyst for the economic downturn the fed sees as a real possibility.  This is likely putting a lot of pressure on Powell to push fwd with rate cuts even if not technically warranted by the Fed's primary objectives. I'm still way up in the air on this one, but much less sure than previously.

This isn't closely related to the update of this forecast, but still interesting:
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/07/29/if-the-fed-cuts-rates-this-week-it-could-widen-a-growing-rift-within-the-central-bank.html

doesn't make sense, but I think the pressure will get to him. He pre-empted it by talking about interest rate cuts as a "vaccine," letting" us know that he is capable of fixing something even when there isn't anything to fix.  That said, cuts don't make sense especially given low inflation.  On monitary policy alone, rates should stay the same or go up, but there has been so much pressure as well as news of global economic woes including the EU who is talking rate change that I think hey'll be bullied into it.  I will update my initial 1/28/71 prediction to give the fed chair the bennefit of the doubt, though.  He also came out with a statement before the fed meeting saying the "vaccine" was a metaphor and not indicative of a plan.  This could have been to scare markets that already priced in a cut so they  have room to jump on the news of a cut and jerome is a hero, but i think this is wishful thinking.

would make sense to raise the rate for borrowing costs as the financial markets especially in uk a watchdog ticked off was cheesed of with all the major auditors in uk thanks to me subject to article in the epping guardian on 27th june 2019 if all uk auditors are not up to standard and federal reserve was underperforming by not listening to me as I predicted the price of gold and Italy is in so much debt and America with china we need to raise costs
97%->100% It doesn't seem like Powell is trying suggest that a rate cut will not happen.

Markets likely to be extremely upset if rates stay the same, after Powell encouraged rate cut expectation.
FED Rational: preventing downside from weak global trends and other things that might go wrong.
Looks like they'll be going down a bit, although not enough to satisfy The Current Incumbent.
Shifting a lot toward lower given market expectations, economic news, and fed signals all suggesting a July rate cut.
Updating from previous as deadline approaches. 1 month and 3 month treasury yields(<2.15%) are way below current fed target (~2.4). Could the Market be this wrong?

Any decent Fed chair understands that you have to respect expectations that you helped create. So I think a cut, even if it's tiny, will be in order. There's not much risk of inflation getting out of control with a small cut now that can be walked back later if there's an obvious strengthening. People who haven't studied macroeconomics to at least an intermediate level may not understand how critical expectations are. It might be useful to google "central banking" and "expectations".
Powell's testimony in Congress suggested a rate reduction in the next meeting, even though other fed chiefs disagree.

The markets are pricing in a 100% certainty that the Fed will lower rates at the late July meeting, so I changed my bet to 100% for "Lower."  But there is very little to gain in Brier points between 80% or 90% and 100%, and the downside for being wrong is huge.  I've learned this the hard way.  I'll back off my prediction to 87%, with 13% for "Same."

Increasing chance of rate cut by 15%. Updating from Powell's recent comments in front of Congress  https://www.google.com/amp/s/mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKCN1U627N And the 1 month treasury yield is at 2.15% which is a decent indication that the market expects one or more quarter point rate cuts.

By Matt Egan, CNN Business: "Central banks are supposed to set policy for markets, not the other way around. It's never a good idea to let the inmates run the asylum."
https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6554778831868174336
What a brilliant move that would be!
While a disagree with the decision to cut rates, it looks almost certain they will. Increasing probability of lower rates from 85 to 97%.
The Fed chairman all but said he would lower interest rates in the fall. There is substantial evidence that the global economy might be slowing.

Yet to find a rational reason for flat rates in light of Powell's comments yesterday. The one small bit was his point that "the base case" is still for a strong economy (which supports no cut. However, the testimony, June meeting minutes, and financial markets all suggest there has been no sign of economic improvement from the Fed's perspective and that a rate cut may spur some growth/inflation

Markets are pricing a 100% chance of a rate cut [1] ~~~
Base rate
~~~ In all cases where the CME tool has shown 100% chance of a rate cut, there has been a rate cut [2], implying a base rate of 100% ~~~
Inside view
~~~ The base rate confirms my impression of the Fed’s signals but to combat confirmation bias, I look for disconfirming evidence. A good article on this is [2]. Reasons the Fed might not cut rates include a strong labor market. In fact, the latest US confirm payrolls came in very strong at 224,000, far above expectations.  Another is a cooling of tensions between the US and China, which was mentioned at the June Fed meeting as a factor the Fed was watching.  On the other hand, Powell's latest comments from today's testimony suggests he continues to see uncertainty in the economic outlook, which he flagged as a concern in June. [3] Given the context of June comments, his testimony in the House today indicates a dovish approach [3]. [1] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html
[2] https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-07-03/can-anything-delay-the-inevitable-july-fed-rate-cut
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/881261
Leading indicators + futures overwhelmingly say end of July cut. Powell will try to sate all stakeholders with -25 bps.

What is the interpretation of the media about Jerome Powell's speech today: The Fed will cut rate this month:
https://edition.cnn.com/2019/07/10/business/federal-reserve-powell-house-testimony/index.html

https://www.cbsnews.com/news/federal-reserve-chairman-jay-powell-no-evidence-hot-labor-market-wages-low/
https://nypost.com/2019/07/10/fed-chair-jerome-powell-is-just-saying-what-trump-wants-to-hear/ I'll keep on searching, but for the moment, it seems chances have changed strongly to lower.
@1MM1 makes a convincing case (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/881312). I'm holding a mere 1% for unexpected bumps in the road between now and the Fed's July meeting.
I'm sold. 20 days to FOMC meeting and my inside view is crushed and buried by the mm managers and Powell. Convinced. A real Keynes-moment for me.
+10 to Lower. I didn't read the details yet so consider this a kneejerk adjustment in response to news that confirms my priors, just in case I don't get time to look at this for a few days.

Case for lower rates has strengthened significantly based on Powell’s comments today. The concern seems to be not on addressing any current weakness, but rather perceived weaknesses farther into the future. These concerns include:
- inflation hasn’t picked up yet 
- business confidence is falling due to trade disputes
- housing starts are low
- global growth is declining in the face of trade uncertainty All of these factors seems to support an insurance cut to boost spending and investment. Previous analyses would suggest I should move from 24% to 90% probability of a rate cut. I’m only going to go half way until I have more time to think about this and analyze Powell’s comments.

Base rate: 100% Lower
From Bianco Research: Since February 1994, the Fed has had 201 planned meetings plus other gatherings where they made changes to monetary policy. Once a meeting is only 27 trading days away, the market has correctly predicted the Fed’s actions 87% of the time. “Since 1994, we cannot find an instance when the market’s implied odds hit 100% within 35 days of the next meeting without the Fed delivering,” Inside view:100% Lower
Powell's latest comments signal that Fed is going to cut rates at the end of the month.
https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-07-10/jerome-powell-leaves-no-doubt-about-fed-rate-cut-in-july?srnd=premium-europe

Per WSJ, Powell’s latest comments are more on the dovish side than before: “After Fed officials agreed to hold rates steady last month, Mr. Powell strongly suggested they could cut rates in the months ahead if an economic outlook clouded by uncertainty over trade policy and weakening global growth didn’t improve.
Since last month’s meeting, “it appears that uncertainties around trade tensions and concerns about the strength of the global economy continues to weigh on the U.S. economic outlook,” Mr. Powell said in testimony prepared for delivery to the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday morning. “Inflation pressures remain muted,” he added.” To watch:
* Powell testimony in the House on Wednesday this week and the Senate on Thursday. [1] https://apple.news/AE64gvU4FQbqddPqfAIwT1A

https://apnews.com/cb9f9a4158c245c08d2e8df05ed19cbc
Strange days at the Fed, as elsewhere.  Coming up a bit on Same, but with absolutely no confidence.
Positive jobs report. Short end of the treasury curve is still indicating a drop in fed rate as likely. 1 month treas is ~2.25%. Reducing chance of rate cut by 5%.

The robust employment gain in June makes a rate cut less likely for the July Fed meeting [1].  A  rate cut is still possible in September but it is beyond the timeframe of this question. [1]  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-07-05/u-s-jobs-top-forecast-as-224-000-gain-dilutes-case-for-fed-cut
Adjusting downwards due to strong jobs report. Will be paying attention to Powell's comments next week before adjusting massively downwards/upwards.

A lot of people have been citing the CME FedWatch Tool here. An interesting article (below) discusses how the probabilities are derived: https://finance.yahoo.com/news/swiss-watch-finance-where-fed-221110286.html What I couldn't find was much quantitative data on how accurate the aggregated forecasts are, so I did a little (unscientific) research of my own. The CME allows you to download data on predictions for past rate hikes. Unfortunately, I could only find historical data for the last 3 months (Mar - Jun). The results, however, are intriguing. The average Brier Score (over a 1 year period) is about 0.34. What is more interesting is that if you just look at Brier Scores over a 1 month period (time until question ends), the average for the last 3 meetings is almost perfect at about 0.01.  This analysis is obviously quite limited by its' sample size, but I could not find additional data. One other factor that could reduce confidence is that expectations were pretty clear for the March and April meetings and there was strong consensus around how the Fed would act. However, the last meeting (June) had a lot more uncertainty around it and the Brier Score reflected that (0.05 in the 30 days prior to the June meeting instead of >0.01 for the other 2 months). Based on this information, Bayes Theorem tells me I should go from 24% to 85% on the probability of a rate cut, but I'm not so sure. That being said, I'm still having trouble understanding the rate cut argument outside of the market feedback loop (i.e. the markets will get what they expect in order to sustain the expansion) described in this article.  https://seekingalpha.com/article/4273215-2-loops At the end of the day, it just doesn't jive with the Fed's stated position of being data-dependent and honoring their dual mandate of employment and inflation to "sustain the expansion". Trade talks are back on (though the consensus view of their success is skeptical, but I think that matters more later in the year), inflation picked up in June, job growth is steady (though the devil may be in the details of wage growth and unemployment), and growth remains solid. While concerns are certainly materializing I don't see a real case outside of the market talked themselves into it. All of this is a long way of saying I'm going to stick with my current forecast because I think the market is ignoring some key fundamentals and over-reacting to a volatile, late-cycle environment that is coinciding with the Trade Dispute. I have got to be missing something - just not sure what it is...
Labor report - way to lower level Consumer price index report 11july ???

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy/u-s-job-growth-seen-accelerating-rate-cut-still-expected-idUSKCN1U00AF

https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html But here is interesting article from Bloomberg what needs to happen for FED to delay cut:
https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-07-03/can-anything-delay-the-inevitable-july-fed-rate-cut
The futures market is predicting a 95% probability of lowering rates by mid year.
Shifting 15 points toward lower given market expectations and continued trade issues.
Some indicators have been coming in below expectations or on the soft side, such as construction spending (residential and non-).  Put 4 more points into Lower.
The trade truce may make this slightly less urgent. To watch: CPI data release for June on July 11.
The 1 month is below the fed funds range.

Updating based on results of G20 meeting between Trump and Xi. My last forecast indicated that a positive development from the meeting (agreement to restart talks with some concessions from each side) would support a wait-and-see approach. Two factors, however, are keeping me just below a 1 in 4 chance:
1. The market is pricing a decrease in and (see comments in my last forecast) the self-fulfilling feedback loop may require Powell and company to follow through due to a perceived "need" 
2. Slowing global growth concerns (especially relative to trend GDP) suggest the need for a rate cut even if inflation bounces back to 2% Ultimately, I think factor two is more relevant in late Q3 or Q4, Powell and team still have significant credibility to talk the market off the ledge if the data supports them, and data is not deteriorating fast enough for the Fed to act with a possible trade deal on the horizon.

US and China are friends again [1].
US is looking for ways to negotiate a new deal and Iran desperately needs the sanction released [2].
Inflation is stubbornly low [3]. What can go wrong? [1] https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/jun/29/us-china-trade-talks-back-on-track-says-trump
[2] https://www.economist.com/briefing/2019/06/29/breaking-the-nuclear-deal-ratchets-up-the-conflict-between-iran-and-america
[3] https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/inflation-cpi

PCE rose to 2% in May suggesting that inflation picked up slightly and income and spending rose (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-06-28/u-s-core-inflation-shows-signs-of-life-as-fed-weighs-rate-cut). While these factors are not enough to make me think an increase is imminent (growth and inflation are still in line with expectations and risks remain), it certainly strengthens the "hold" argument A deeper dive into Fed comments suggest they will act "as needed". What outcomes would justify a need? In my opinion:
1. Trade talks devolve and tariffs rise. Consensus prediction from major bank analysts is that there will be a pause on future increases coming out of this weekend 
2. PCE falls to 1.5 - 1.7% for June, Unemployment to rise by 0.2% or more, falling business confidence Another, less quantitative factor that keeps me above a 1 in 4 chance of a decrease is this desire by the Fed to lead markets and not just respond to economic data. At the end of the day, the inter-connected global economy and market feedback loops are just as risky to Fed policy independence as the Presidents' tweets. For instance, markets rise on expectations of a cut, the Fed holds flat, markets fall due to a repricing of the discount rate, falling markets decrease sentiment, confidence, investment, spending, and ultimately inflation, and growth which raises the recessionary risks the Fed is trying to fight.  That being said, I think a productive G20 (75% likely), stabilizing data and no new GDP figures (most of it is already out, 50% probability for good June numbers), and continued earnings strength reaffirm the case for a "wait-and-see" through Q3.
Based on Powell and other FOMC members' speeches, it seems pretty likely that they are going to cut rates on their July meeting date, which would reduce the upper limit by 25 bps.
The economy is weakening, but we are only a few weeks a way from the deadline.
Powell in comments today said the Fed would follow a “wait and see” approach. I am therefore lowering chance of a rate cut.

The market is pricing a 100% probability of a rate cut at the end July meeting. It is likely to oblige, possibly against the instincts of many on its Board, squeezed as it is between Trump and the market. It's being called an insurance cut, rather than one that's immediately required.
Fed Funds Futures currently put odds of a cut in the rate by July at 100%. So the rate will be lower, but it's not automatic that the upper limit has to be lowered.

Fed seems to be on pause and there are countervailing forces that would suggest a hike while others would point to patience/a cut. I tend to believe interest rates are too low but I know FOMC participants disagree.
Likely that the Federal Reserve will lower the Fed Funds Rate at the end of July.
It is coming, sooner or later.

Increasing slightly because...
1) There is only one meeting left before the question ends
2) The statement supports a data-driven approach which will wait and see how US economic data evolves - this reduces my faith in the "insurance" argument
3) I'm expecting positive sentiment from the Trump/Xi meeting, but no solid deal. This cautious optimism would support flat rates. That being said...
1) Markets are pricing in a higher probability of a rate cut in July
2) A list of "top" economist seems to think a cut is likely in July
3) The Taylor Rule/Inflation reading imply a cut is needed 
4) The most recent dot plot suggests 47% of the FOMC supports a rate cut in 2019
Shifting toward lower as that's what the markets seem to be predicting this year. I don't think it is likely to happen in the next six weeks but I am realizing it is possible.
Markets now pricing 100% probability of July rate cut: https://twitter.com/Schuldensuehner/status/1141411016518934528?s=19
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/06/19/fed-decision-fed-leaves-rates-unchanged.html This was expected, still no cuts in 2019, but pointing that the economic activity is rising at a moderate rate...

The perception of the global economy’s health seems to be rapidly changing. Everyone is going dovish now (see Draghi’s statement in Sintra today), and the Fed will likely follow suit   in its statement. However, there is a (moderate) chance that the easing will start only from September, as not everyone on the FOMC is super-dovish.

Nothing pushing expectations for a hike.  June seems too soon for a cut. Need stronger inflation numbers to rule out a cut. 2 to 0 higher
51 to 41 same
47 to 59 lower

Consumer price inflation in May was only 1.8%, far below the 2% target by the Fed, suggesting a more likely willingness to act. https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/06/13/the-market-believes-the-fed-will-cut-rates-by-september-should-it

An interesting article about the wisdom of the crowd. Following it, adjusted by time of reaction. https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/06/13/the-market-believes-the-fed-will-cut-rates-by-september-should-it
https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html The market is expecting a lower rate with a probability of 88.7% !

A cut in the June meeting is unlikely - too soon, and the economy is not that bad. July 31 is another matter - the first estimate of GDP growth for Q2 will be out, and it's likely to be weak - regional Fed banks predict 1-1.4 percent. Moreover, the Trump-Xi meeting in late June - that may shed more light on the trade wars - will have happened. Normally, the Fed waits longer between hinting at a change of course and actually doing it, so I don't assign a large probability of a cut, but the markets do - the CME futures assign a 78% probability. Will update after the Fed meeting next week - the language in the public statement may have hints.
It looks like general expectations are now favoring a cut. Fuel prices softening, and Trump backing off his threat of retaliatory tariffs on Mexico, could help avoid the need for a cut.

now that Mexico is celebrating, and with a 3.1 trillion dollar quantitative easing asset balance  and at current rates monetary policy is still historically accomodative.
If I were on Fed I would continue to push rates higher. I am not.
Powell is and the stock market and Trump and tariffs have created an awkward feedback loop.
I have never failed to forecast an interest rate move.
If the Fed is going to move July is the time.and its going down.
I am pulling back from 90 due to the Presidential decision to spare Mexico for now.
Beware of Tariff Man and his advisers.
If the stock indexes continue to soar time enough to reappraise

Shifting back in the original direction where Same > Lower > Higher I need to read more about the jobs report and do a little more research.  I can see reasons for why it's not as weak as some would argue. With unemployment already low the labor market could end up tapped out. Current 2Q GDP forecasts are landing between 1-2%. Not bad but not overheating, which means we should expect inflation to remain low to moderate.
Just heard in the news that the futures market is pricing in nearly an 80% chance of a rate cut in July.

The headline in the FT was "US job growth slows in May with just 75,000 added."  So it was a weaker than expected employment report.  That marginally boosts the chances of a rate cut announcement on July 1.

There was a strong employment report this morning.  The opinion on Wall Street seems to be that this does nothing to the chances that the Fed will lower rates by the end of the year.  I have read in the financial press that the futures market is pricing a 90% chance of a cut by the end of 2019.  I know little to nothing about futures, but that's what they are saying. My guess, and that's all it is, is that this news may delay the rate cut until the September meeting or after.  Unless the Fed acts between meetings, which is rare, there is only one more chance for a rate cut before the end of the challenge (August 1). So if you want to game the system, wait until July 1st for the results of the June 30-July 1 Fed meeting.  Then you can bet heavily on the outcome, with a 90%+ chance of being right.  You will only have one month's worth of credit for the challenge, but you'll have a Brier score of near zero.
The worse than expected jobs report from this morning raises the chances for a rate cut.  Raising by 5 percentage points.

-Trade tensions with China and Mexico are increasing risks for the US economy
-Jobs report is expected to suggest a slowing labor market
-Fed may wish to take some "insurance" against a weak economy
-Risk of failing to act seems to be higher than the risk of waiting to act given the low rate environment
-Inflation is remaining persistently low but...
-Fed is data-dependent and most indicators suggest (comparatively) the US is on strong footing
-Trade War could fizzle out (Mexico wants a deal, China is likely waiting for Xi and Trump to meet - both countries benefit from a deal)
-With only two meetings until the question wraps up, I think a lot of the reasons the Fed would cut may not materialize until the September meeting
-Fed can still leverage its' balance sheet to buy Treasuries and increase the money supply - effectively lowering rates

"Jerome Powell, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, reassured financial markets rattled by growing trade tensions. Speaking at a conference in Chicago, Mr Powell said the central bank would “act as appropriate to sustain the expansion” amid growing economic uncertainty. The remarks sparked a rally in American share prices and signalled the Fed’s willingness to cut interest rates. Futures markets indicate a 59% chance of a rate cut by July." https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2019/06/08/business-this-week
Stepping up to the plate, but not ready to hit. The FED meeting on Jun 19th and Jul 31st, so more information to be had. The Tariffs leading to a rate cut? Tbd.

The question is now focused on the Fed's July meeting.  The market is giving a roughly 50% chance of a rate cut then, and a 90% chance by the end of the year.  Will the Fed act in July, or wait until September?  It's a toss up.  If the Trump administration keeps pushing hard for tariffs on Mexico it will cause a weakening of the economy.  Auto manufacturing and auto parts will be hit hard.
and thé anémic ADP jobs report and rates are going down

futures markets see a 70% chance of a rate cut by July https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html (i.e. June or July meeting. A lot depends on tariffs https://www.forbes.com/sites/simonmoore/2019/06/04/how-tariffs-may-prompt-a-summer-rate-cut/#2dc68fc453a0, but given things were pretty finely balanced pre-tariffs moving up to 25% I do think tariffs could push them to a cut. I see the main risk to that view that (1) tariffs are reversed (could happen fast) (2) the cut doesn't happen until the Sept meeting. There are downside risks too though e.g. (1) Mexico tariffs if they happen (2) the prospect of car tariffs (2) equity market panic causing Fed to step in (3) further weakness in manufacturing/housing or consumer spending weakening further (4) the yield curve is inverted and the Fed worries about that. We'll learn a lot more in the Fed June meeting, if the statement and the 'dot plot' don't carry a large signal a rate cut is imminent then I think a surprise rate cut in July is becomes far less likely. So the June Fed meeting is a critical datapoint here.

Re-iterating my previous forecast.  The target range for the federal funds rate is almost certain to stay the same until 01 August, with an outside chance it might be lowered. As far as I can tell, the Fed might change the federal funds rate under two circumstances: (1) to fulfill its charter of minimizing unemployment and stabilizing prices, or (2) in response to outside (i.e., political, market) pressure. Unemployment is the lowest it's been in 50 years or so.  It's hard to imagine the Fed needs to do anything about that.  In other words, it doesn't need to lower the rate to help fire up the economy for the purpose of lowering unemployment. At the same time, inflation is running persistently lower than the Fed's target rate of 2%.  So the Fed does not need to raise rates to cool off the economy. But the Fed is in a bind, because this sort of very low unemployment and very low inflation aren't supposed to co-exist in the Fed's models (sort of similar, but in reverse, of the stagflation of the late-70s and early-80s). With unemployment this low and inflation this low, the Fed will not raise rates soon for the standard reasons.  But they are quasi-obsessed with the persistent low inflation, and there are voices calling for lowering the federal funds rate to help put some spark in the economy in order to raise inflation. On policy grounds, I think this is unlikely. First, the rate is already very low by historic standards.  This is one of the tools the Fed uses during a recession, and if they lower it, they will be hamstringing themselves should a recession come (and there are strong indicators of one in the next year or so).   Second, there is also serious discussion of reviewing the Fed's framework for inflation, to see if maybe it's time to rethink how they view inflation.  If that happens, I don't see them lowering it until that review has been completed. Third, the recent FOMC minutes indicate that, for the most part, the Fed plans to be patient and see how inflation plays out.  And since the last FOMC meeting, most of the FOMC's voting members have gone on record as saying they are happy with things for now, and there's no need to change the rate. So in terms of the Fed doing anything based solely on its charter, I think the rate will stay the same through 01 August. Then there's outside pressure. The President wants rates lowered, and he's made no secret of it. But whereas at one point I thought that might have undue influence on the Fed, the recent implosions of Trump nominees Stephen Moore and Herman  Cain make me think that the Senate does, after all, have some backbone and will stand up to Trump from time to time regarding certain issues.  Central banking appears to be one of those issues, and I am inclined to think that the Fed now knows that the Senate has its back, and thus it can proceed to make decisions based on policy without too much regard for political pressure. There is also the so-called "Fed Put."  As I understand it, this is the idea that the Fed actually takes the status of the stock market into account when making these decisions.  The market's been having some bad days lately due to the trade war thing, and it's conceivable that should things really go downhill, the Fed might lower rates to help give it some juice. That's possible, but I think it's unlikely.  The market's problems are basically Trump-induced, and to respond to that would be in many ways responding to Trump's calls for lowering the rate.  Again, possible, but unlikely. So all in all, I think that on 01 August we'll wake up with the same target range as we see today.

All of the debate centered around the slowing of the economy and the need to preempt a further decrease in inflation.  In March the FOMC stated a change would not occur for the rest of the year. I really think the Fed is frozen for a while.  This challenge ends on August 1 -- that's only 97 days.  More importantly, the FOMC is scheduled to meet June 12-13 and again on July 31-Aug 1.  This leaves two opportunities for a change in the Fed Funds Rate.  Unless the economy accelerates unexpectedly there won't be any rate increase.  But after the 3.2% growth just reported for Q1 there probably won't be  enough weakness to warrant a cut either.  But the chance of a cut appears to be higher than for an increase. The Fed was pretty clear yesterday that it's not going to raise rates this year, and I think that makes the case that the probability it won't raise rates before 01 August practically nil.  I don't think the economy will heat up enough between now and then to precipitate a change of course in that direction. On the other hand, both the global and U.S. economies seem to be slowing down and one can conceive the possibility of rates being lowered to stimulate things.  But with rates as low as they already are, I think the Fed would be hugely reluctant to lower them any time soon barring a full bore recession.  I think in the face of a softening economy they'll be more inclined to ease up more on the QT front rather than lower rates anytime soon.

Some mild tweaking of the probabilities, but I still think it is likely the upper limit of the  target range will remain unchanged. The two measures of inflation -- CPI and PPI -- are very low.  Furthermore, as far as I can tell both the Fed and many economists are confused about why this is so with such a tight labor market.  But that is indeed the case.  One or  both of those would have to move upward significantly for the Fed to raise the upper limit on the target range.  That is certainly a possibility, but until we start seeing signs of it, I will discount the probability. On the other hand, I find it equally unlikely the Fed will lower rates between now and then.  Based on many economic indicators, the U.S. economy is doing OK.  A drop in GDP this quarter or next might well be attributed to one-offs like the trade war and the government shut down.  Until we see signs that the U.S. economy is significantly slacking and heading into recession territory due to structural weaknesses, I think it's unlikely that the Fed will lower rates. And what is the Fed saying? Two weeks ago two key Fed officials opined that they don't see a rate hike before this summer. On 12 Feb Jerome Powell said he saw the U.S. economy as being in pretty good shape. Finally, San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly said two things this past week in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. First, she said there is a good chance the U.S. central bank won’t raise interest rates in 2019. “If the economy evolves as I just said I expect it to—2% growth, 1.9% inflation, no sense that [price pressures are] going up, no sense that we have any acceleration—then I think the case for a rate increase isn’t there this year."  More interesting, she suggested that the central bank could decide to use its balance sheet as a routine part of how it guides the economy, not just as a last-ditch measure to deploy in emergencies. This strikes me as perhaps being a trial balloon to gauge reaction.  If the Fed can use its balance sheet to make tweaks, it can leave interest rates alone.  I have seen in more than one opinion piece that the Fed really doesn't want to lower rates again to deal with a slowdown, because that would leave it with less leverage should a recession come along.   Bottom line, in the absence of some compelling reason to change course, I think the current range is what we'll most likely wake up to on 01 Aug.
Interest rate normalization will have to continue.

The CME FedWatch Tool (https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html) is saying 93% for the July meeting. However, independent probabilities would suggest that if the prior meeting has no impact on upcoming meetings (potentially dangerous assumption), then the probability of the Fed staying in the next 4 meetings is 85%. One thing that makes me feel better about my assumption is that each meeting's minutes will provide information to make an update.  I tried to use the Taylor Rule to inform my forecast, but that is highly dependent on the estimate of the neutral rate given that the other variables (GDP & inflation) are so close to their long-term trend. Based on the Fed's recent statements, they are pretty close to where they perceive the neutral rate to be. Factors that could keep the rate the same:
- Fed is promoting a dovish stance
- Data is pointing to a slowdown in growth, but not a decline in growth or sizable increase in inflation
- Phillips Curve has yet to really carry inflation higher
- Business confidence seems highly dependent on the Fed (listen to some earnings calls), and so the FOMC is probably watching I/S ratios and other measures of confidence closely. This would suggest that they would not want to be too aggressive  Factors that would push it higher:
- Inflation (all the bullets are technically inflation, but I broke them out anyway)
- Trade War raises input costs 
- Phillip's Curve finally drives sufficient wage growth
- Wealth Effect (through housing or - more likely - market returns) increases spending
- Increasing food/energy costs - could put pressure on products in Core CPI Factors that could drive a rate cut:
- US tips into a recession before July, 2019
- Something causes a massive deleveraging in the corporate bond market and the Fed is forced to step in Overall, I think the Fed is taking a wait-and-see with the impact of tarriffs on inflation and they are still waiting for low employment to translate to higher wages, more consumer spending, and inflation. Further, they are keenly aware of their impact on equity markets and seem more concerned about overshooting than undershooting. To change my position to an increase, I'd need to see a strong uptick in Core CPI data or the markets push considerably higher. A resolution to the Trade War would spark higher confidence in no action as opposed to an increase. The only thing I see pointing to a decrease is a confirmed recession. As such, I'm going with the following:
Same: 88%
Lower: 4%
Higher: 8%

Initial forecast was 14/74/12. I think until GDP figures come out for 2018 Q4 and 2019 Q1, I feel like it is best to remain cautious and reserve a few more points for a decrease. I'm expecting to see a slowdown relative to the strongest quarters of last year, and I don't see inflation picking up much. I think the chance of an increase is probably lower than I thought due to how the Fed slammed the brakes. I agree with economists who believe the December hike was a mistake. I don't think we'll hit a recession in the next 6 months, but it is possible some shock or slowdown appears on the horizon and the Fed decides to take action.

My initial forecast is 9% (higher), 90% (same), and 1% (lower). It was tough figuring out a base rate for this. At least it was for me.  We are in a somewhat unique historic situation with respect to rate changes, and I didn’t quite know how to consider past situations. So I took another track.  I looked at how many forecasters had scored high on previous leaderboards, then averaged out their current forecasts.  Then I focused on the the strongest estimate (hint: it was “Same”). So I began with that average for “Same”, and then started factoring things in. The WSJ reported on 5 Feb that Fed Dallas Federal Reserve Bank President Robert Kaplan said he believes the U.S. central bank will hold off on rate increases until at least the summer.  And of 7 Feb the WSJ reported that St. Louis Fed leader James Bullard said the central bank doesn’t need to raise rates any further to achieve its job and inflation goals. Furthermore, the CME Fed Watch site has mid- to high-90s probability that the upper limit on the rate will not go higher over the next four meetings. Finally, in a Bloomberg article today on the Fed’s next steps, it says: “In addition to the encouraging pace of employment creation, the last jobs report supplied the Fed with indications of remaining slack in the labor market. The direct evidence came in the form of a further pickup in labor-force participation, which illustrated the potential for more people re-entering the labor market. Further proof was provided by the relatively stable wage-growth number that prevails notwithstanding the JOLTS and jobless claims data that would suggest otherwise. You can add to that signs of a productivity pick up after years of unusually low growth.” In short, there are two things the Fed could respond to: increased inflation (raise rates) or significantly decreased economic activity (lower rates).  Between now and 01 August it appears the odds slightly favor increased inflation over significantly decreased economic activity.  Thus I think the probability of a rate hike is slightly higher than a rate decrease.  But I think the preponderance of the probability goes to no change at this point.

The US and global economies will experience an acceleration of growth or the deceleration with intensify.  Monetary policy with continue to tighten or it will substantially eases, but not stay the same.

NYT even notes Fed ready to pause on interest rates [2]. Until the last Fed meetign most economists expected a few more steps over the course of the year, but the Fed has become clelarly more dovish. Actually, the signs that the US economy has crossed the peak and will cool down are increasing. Moreover, inflation is low so there is no need to hike the rated. However, the US economy is still growing and unemployment is low and, moreover, the Fed might want to show that the Trump government has no impact on its decisions, so the chance that the Fed will increase the Fed funds rate is clearly above zero.

A lower rate would feed cheap money into a  system that does not need it: rates are already historically low and this would add gas to the balloon. A higher rate would be very unpopular in the White House, but would have an economic justification to take some of the fizz out of speculation. It would also be high in global terms and so attractive to foreign investors (I'd love to get 3% on some TIPS). However, that would strengthen the dollar, at a time when imports of basic materials are likely to get more expensive anyway (tariffs) and exports are looking for new markets (soybeans etc).  The least-worst is to keep it the same, but there's a period in the year I've nicknamed 'the guns of August' when weird stuff can happen, so will revisit this later.
